head.title: Development of Dopant-Free Donor–Acceptor-type Hole Transporting Material for Highly Efficient and Stable Perovskite Solar Cells | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Development of Dopant-Free Donor–Acceptor-type Hole Transporting Material for Highly Efficient and Stable Perovskite Solar Cells

In perovskite solar cells (PSCs), overlying hole transporting materials (HTMs) are important for achieving high efficiencies as well as protecting perovskite active layers from degradation factors. This study reports the synthesis of a dopant-free HTM based on a D′–A–D–A–D–A–D′ (D, D′: electron donor, A: electron acceptor) conjugated structure and incorporation of the HTM into a PSC. The resulting PSC exhibits a high efficiency of 17.3%, which is comparable to that of the device based on doped spiro-OMeTAD HTM, and exhibits much improved stability: without encapsulation, the PSC based on the new HTM was found to retain 80% of its initial performance over 500 h under the conditions of 60% relative humidity/1 sun light-soaking without encapsulation. The high performance is attributed to efficient hole-extraction/collection and hole transport. We demonstrate that the extended π-structure of the D′–A–D–A–D–A–D′-type HTM slows moisture intrusion and protects the perovskite layer better than smaller D–A-type molecules. The improved stability is primarily due to the hydrophobic nature of the HTM; the relatively large π-conjugated molecule forms denser films, which effectively decrease the spaces between the molecules and retard water intrusion. The dopant-free D–A-type HTM with an extended π-structure is effective not only in improving device efficiency, but also device stability.

div.p: In perovskite solar cells (PSCs), overlying hole transporting materials (HTMs) are important for achieving high efficiencies as well as protecting perovskite active layers from degradation factors. This study reports the synthesis of a dopant-free HTM based on a D′–A–D–A–D–A–D′ (D, D′: electron donor, A: electron acceptor) conjugated structure and incorporation of the HTM into a PSC. The resulting PSC exhibits a high efficiency of 17.3%, which is comparable to that of the device based on doped spiro-OMeTAD HTM, and exhibits much improved stability: without encapsulation, the PSC based on the new HTM was found to retain 80% of its initial performance over 500 h under the conditions of 60% relative humidity/1 sun light-soaking without encapsulation. The high performance is attributed to efficient hole-extraction/collection and hole transport. We demonstrate that the extended π-structure of the D′–A–D–A–D–A–D′-type HTM slows moisture intrusion and protects the perovskite layer better than smaller D–A-type molecules. The improved stability is primarily due to the hydrophobic nature of the HTM; the relatively large π-conjugated molecule forms denser films, which effectively decrease the spaces between the molecules and retard water intrusion. The dopant-free D–A-type HTM with an extended π-structure is effective not only in improving device efficiency, but also device stability.

div.div:
Organometal-halide perovskites APbX
3
(A = methylammonium, formamidinium; X = Br, I) are often used as photoactive materials in solar cells because of their advantageous properties: strong light absorption with a low-energy bandgap of ∼1.6 eV, low charge carrier loss due to the very long carrier diffusion length, and low nonradiative recombination.
(1-6)
Remarkable advances in perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have been achieved over the last few years, in large part due to improvement in perovskite fabrication techniques and the fine-tuning of perovskite composition. As a result, several research groups have reported power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) above 20%.
(7-9)

To develop highly efficient perovskite solar cells, research has focused on several important issues such as improving the morphology of perovskite films and finding good organic hole transporting materials (HTMs) other than polytriarylamine (PTAA) and 2,2′,7,7′-tetrakis(
N
,
N
-di-
p
-methoxyphenylamine)-9,9′-spirobifluorene (spiro-OMeTAD). Although polymeric HTMs such as PTAA exhibit good processability and high photovoltaic performance,
(2, 10)
their mass distribution (polydispersity), batch-to-batch variation, and lower purity due to residual catalyst and oligomers are inherent drawbacks for commercialization.
(11, 12)
In contrast, small molecule HTMs are attractive from the viewpoint of industrial mass production because they can be produced with a well-defined chemical structure and a precise molecular weight.
(9)
Many small molecule HTMs have been developed that afford high solar cell performances in the range 18–20%. For example, Nazeeruddin and co-workers reported a PSC using a HTM of a methoxyphenylamine-substituted fluorene-dithiophene compound with an efficiency of 20.2%,
(9)
and Jen and co-workers demonstrated a stable PSC using a thermal crosslinking HTM with a PCE of 18.27%.
(13)
An HTM based on a phenylcarbazole and fluorene scaffold was utilized in a PSC, which achieved a PCE of more than 17%.
(14)
PSCs with spiro(fluorene-9,9′-xanthene)-based HTMs were developed by Hagfeldt and co-workers and achieved an efficiency of ∼19.8%.
(15, 16)

In many cases, small molecule HTMs such as spiro-OMeTAD need to be doped with chemical dopants such as lithium-bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)-imide (Li-TFSI)/
tert
-butylpyridine (
t
-BP) followed by oxidation in air to improve their charge transport properties.
(17)
However, it is not easy to precisely control the oxidative level, which can result in problems of device reproducibility.
(18)
Moreover, most dopants used in HTMs are hygroscopic, which means that moisture can readily intrude into the perovskite active layer and induce device degradation.
(19)
Thus, it is vital to develop dopant-free organic HTMs as replacements for spiro-OMeTAD and other dopant-based HTMs. Several small molecule HTMs have been introduced into high performance PSCs. For example, Chen and co-workers synthesized a dopant-free HTM including a truxene core, and the PSC using it showed a PCE of 18.6%.
(20)
Jen and co-workers reported a PSC using a HTM based on triphenylamine-based Michler’s base and tricyanovinylene, which showed a PCE of 17.0%.
(21)
We need to keep developing high performance dopant-free HTMs that show advantageous physical properties for PSC application. Moreover, it is highly important to study the effects of dopant-free HTMs deposited on top of the perovskite layer on PSC stability. Donor–acceptor (D–A) conjugated molecules have the advantages over traditional HTMs, such as spiro-OMeTAD and PTAA, of tunable energy levels and high charge mobility. Yang and co-workers reported a PSC using a D–A-type small molecule HTM, which exhibited a PCE of 16.2%.
(22)

Herein, we report the synthesis and characterization of a novel dopant-free HTM based on a D′–A–D–A–D–A–D′ (D, D′: electron donors, A: electron acceptor) conjugated structure, DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
. We tested its use as a HTM in a perovskite solar cell and investigated the effect of the dopant-free HTM on solar cell properties and device stability. The resulting PSC device achieved a PCE of 17.3% without doping under AM 1.5G (100 mW·cm
–2
) illumination, which is among the highest performance of PSCs introducing D–A-type dopant-free HTMs. This PCE is comparable to that of a PSC we fabricated with doped spiro-OMeTAD, 17.4%, and reflects the highly efficient hole-extraction/collection and balanced electron/hole transport in the developed PSC. Moreover, the stability of the developed PSC device is much superior to that of the device based on doped spiro-OMeTAD under a condition of 60% relative humidity (RH)/1 sun light-soaking.

The 5-fluorobenzo[
c
][1,2,5]thiadiazole (FBT) block is a good electron-accepting moiety for D–A-type conjugated molecules, and its pairing with 4,4-bis(2-ethylhexyl)-4
H
-silolo[3,2-
b
:4,5-
b
′]dithiophene (DTS) effectively stabilizes the quinoidal π-character of the molecule and enhances its planar conformation, which are desirable properties for charge transport.
(23)
For example,
p
-DTS(FBTTh
2
)
2
is known to have good charge transporting properties.
(24)
We prepared a D′–A–D–A–D–A–D′-type HTM by adding FBT and DTS units into
p
-DTS(FBTTh
2
)
2
. The increased molecular size and conjugation length of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
are favorable for the formation of a compact HTM film with a high molecular density due to effective π–π stacking and thus improved charge transport properties.

The synthetic route for DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
is shown in
Figure 1
, and the synthetic conditions and characterization are described in detail in the
Supporting Information
. Firstly, compound 2 was synthesized through the Stille coupling reaction of compound 1 with hexamethylditin. Compound 3 was then introduced at the terminal ends of compound 2 via the Stille coupling reaction, which produced DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
in 59.5% yield. The final product was characterized by performing
1
H NMR spectroscopy and matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization-time-of-flight (MALDI-TOF)/TOF mass spectrometry (
Figures S1 and S2
of the Supporting Information). The thermal properties of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
were determined with thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) (
Figure S3
); the TGA curves indicate that it is thermally stable up to 437 °C. The melting temperature of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
is 271.7 °C according to our differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measurements (
Figure S4
).

div.p:
Figure 1. Synthetic scheme of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
.

div.div:
Figure 2
a shows the UV–vis absorption spectra of the solution and film states of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
. The absorption maximum (λ
max
abs
) and onset points (λ
onset
abs
) in the solution spectrum are at 620 and 690 nm, respectively. The spectrum of the solid state contains a broad optical absorption band with distinct high- and low-energy bands attributed to localized π–π* transitions and intramolecular charge transfer, respectively.
(25)
The maximum and onset absorption in the film are red-shifted with respect to those in the solution spectrum by 104 and 106 nm, respectively, to λ
max
abs
= 724 nm and λ
onset
abs
= 796 nm. This red shift is attributed to the planarization of the conjugated backbone and the efficient intermolecular interactions within the film.
(26, 27)
The energy bandgap (
E
g
opt
) value was estimated from the onset of the film absorption to be 1.56 eV. Cyclic voltammetry was performed in dichloromethane solution to study the electrochemical properties of the compound (
Figure 2
b). The highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels were estimated from the onset oxidation and reduction potentials. The HOMO energy level of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
(−5.27 eV) is 0.14 eV deeper than that of spiro-OMeTAD (−5.13 eV), and is thus better matched with the valence band of MAPbI
3
(−5.43 eV).
(1)

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) Absorption spectra in chloroform solution and of the film, and (b) cyclic voltammetric curve of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
.

div.div:
The charge transport properties in the out-of-plane direction of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
were evaluated by using the space-charge-limited current (SCLC) technique (
Figure S5
). The hole mobility of the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
film is 1.78 × 10
–4
cm
2
·V
–1
·s
–1
, which is comparable to that of lithium-salt-doped spiro-OMeTAD (1–5.2 × 10
–4
cm
2
·V
–1
·s
–1
).
(17, 27-30)
This high mobility means that it can function as an effective HTM without requiring an extra doping process, which simplifies device preparation and is likely to improve solar cell stability.

Figure 3
a shows the time-resolved photoluminescence (TR-PL) profiles of the MAPbI
3
film on quartz, MAPbI
3
/spiro-OMeTAD film, and MAPbI
3
/DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
film; the characteristic parameters are summarized in
Table S1
. The average PL lifetime (τ
avg
) of the perovskite film on quartz was calculated to be 23.24 ns. When the HTM films were coated onto perovskite films, the τ
avg
values were much reduced and found to vary with the HTM. In particular, the τ
avg
value of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
(1.30 ns) is lower than that of spiro-OMeTAD (2.74 ns). We conclude that the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
hole transporting layer (HTL) exhibits faster and more efficient hole extraction from the perovskite layer.

div.p:
Figure 3. (a) TR-PL decay curves of MAPbI
3
in the presence of HTMs; the lines are exponential fits of the data. (b) Device architecture and (c) scanning electron microscopy (SEM) cross-section image of planar heterojunction MAPbI
3
perovskite solar cell with dopant-free DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
HTM. (d) Energy diagram.

div.div:
Planar heterojunction perovskite solar cells were fabricated (
Figure 3
b) to assess the effectiveness of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
as an HTM for hole extraction. The device consisted of a layer of MAPbI
3
(∼300 nm) on a planar TiO
2
(∼50 nm)/FTO substrate, and it was fabricated by using the one-step deposition method (see
Supporting Information
). HTMs were then spin-coated onto the perovskite layer, including spiro-OMeTAD doped with
t
-BP + Li-TFSI and the dopant-free DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
. Finally, the Au (∼60 nm) metal electrode was deposited on the HTM/MAPbI
3
/TiO
2
/FTO substrate by thermal evaporation. The cross-sectional scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image (
Figure 3
c) revealed that the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
layer has a thickness of ∼40 nm and is uniformly sandwiched between the perovskite layer and the gold contact, and that the perovskite film is dense and uniform with a polycrystalline structure, as is consistent with previous reports.
(31)
Figure 3
d shows the energy band diagram of the perovskite and HTMs investigated in this study. The HOMO energy level of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
is slightly lower (−5.27 eV) than those of intrinsic spiro-OMeTAD (−5.13 eV) and even doped spiro-OMeTAD (−5.22 eV),
(27)
and it is well-matched with that of the MAPbI
3
absorber for hole extraction.

Figure 4
a,b shows the current density–voltage (
J
–
V
) curves for the best device under the 1 sun condition (100 mW·cm
–2
AM 1.5G illumination). The results are summarized in
Table 1
. The best device yields a high PCE of 17.3% with an open circuit voltage (
V
OC
) of 1.1 V, a short circuit current density (
J
SC
) of 20.7 mA·cm
–2
, and a fill factor (FF) of 76.0% in the reverse scan condition (1.2 V → −0.05 V). In the forward scan direction (−0.05 V → 1.2 V), a PCE of 17.0% was observed with a
V
OC
of 1.1 V, a
J
SC
of 20.7 mA·cm
–2
, and a FF of 74.5%. No apparent hysteresis was detected during the forward or reverse scans. The external quantum efficiency (EQE) spectrum of the perovskite solar cell, shown in
Figure 4
c, is consistent with the measured
J
SC
. Doped spiro-OMeTAD was tested with the same device architecture and found to exhibit a PCE of around 17.4% with a
V
OC
of 1.1 V, a
J
SC
of 20.5 mA·cm
–2
, and a FF of 77.0% in the forward scan, which are comparable to those obtained for the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
-based devices. Although the LUMO energy level of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
(−3.86 eV) is lower than that of spiro-OMeTAD (−2.09 eV), this energy level appears to be sufficient to block electron transfer from the perovskite layer to the HTM and minimize charge recombination. Also, the electron-rich property of D–A-type small molecular HTMs might be effective for suppressing such electron transfer because the HTM would prefer not to take more electrons from the perovskite layer. Clearly, the dopant-free DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
HTM efficiently collects holes from the perovskite layer and transports them to the metal electrode without the assistance of chemical dopants. Furthermore, the high FF indicates the presence of balanced electron/hole transport via the ETM/HTM layers with low competing recombination.
(32)
Note that the EQE line shapes of the devices with DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
and spiro-OMeTAD HTMs appear slightly different; in the range of 550–750 nm, EQEs of the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
-based solar cell are a little decreased compared to the corresponding values of spiro-OMeTAD. This current loss is probably related to light absorption by the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
HTL.
Figure 4
d,e shows histograms of the PCE deviations of 30 solar cell devices. The average PCE values were 15.77 ± 0.94 and 15.68 ± 0.99% for DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
and spiro-OMeTAD, respectively. Overall, DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
-based perovskite solar cells exhibit good device reproducibility.

div.p:
Figure 4. Photovoltaic properties of planar MAPbI
3
perovskite solar cells with (a) dopant-free DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
and (b) doped spiro-OMeTAD. (c) EQE spectra of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
- and spiro-OMeTAD-based solar cells. Deviation of average power conversion efficiency of 30 solar cells using (d) DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
and (e) spiro-OMeTAD.

div.div:
Table 1. Summary of Photovoltaic Properties of Planar MAPbI
3
Perovskite Solar Cells with Different HTMs

Perovskite solar cells are known to degrade under conditions of high humidity and light exposure.
(33, 34)
The stability of the optimized perovskite solar cell devices was tested under the condition of 60% RH in combination with 1 sun light-soaking without encapsulation. The solar cell devices with doped spiro-OMeTAD and DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
HTMs were found to exhibit an initial current density of 18.1 and 17.4 mA·cm
–2
, respectively. During stressing, the efficiency of the doped spiro-OMeTAD-based device fell markedly and no power output was detected after 50 h (
Figure 5
). This result implies that the doped spiro-OMeTAD films cannot prevent moisture intrusion and degradation of the perovskite layer, which is mainly due to the hygroscopic nature of Li-TFSI. In contrast, the performance of the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
-based device is close to its initial performance after 50 h, and after 500 h of stressing (
Figure 5
), the device is operational with 80% performance retention, which demonstrates that the developed HTM is favorable for improving the stability of perovskite solar cells. We also performed stability tests under a relative humidity of 60%, and as shown in
Figure S6
, the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
-based device showed much better stability than that of the spiro-OMeTAD-based one.

div.p:
Figure 5.
J
sc
evolution of perovskite solar cells over time under 60% RH/1 sun light-soaking conditions without encapsulation (
J
sc
values of the devices were continuously measured every 5 min).

div.div:
The contact angles of water on the HTMs were measured and are shown in
Figure 6
a; the values are 92.7 ± 0.17 and 71.9 ± 0.15° for DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
and doped spiro-OMeTAD, respectively. The measured contact angles indicate the responses of the HTM surfaces to water and are related to the moisture permeabilities of the HTMs. Therefore, DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
is more hydrophobic, i.e., it keeps moisture away from the perovskite film, which results in enhanced device stability.

div.p:
Figure 6. (a) Water contact angle images of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
and doped spiro-OMeTAD HTMs. (b) Absorption spectra of MAPbI
3
/HTM films before (linear line) and after (dashed line) H
2
O drop. (c) Comparison of absorbance reduction at 700 nm (
A
red
(%)) of MAPbI
3
/HTMs films after H
2
O drop. (d) SEM cross-section images of MAPbI
3
/HTM films before (left) and after (right) H
2
O drop.

div.div:
To study how the identity of the HTL affects perovskite degradation, we prepared MAPbI
3
/HTM bilayers and then compared their degrees of perovskite degradation when exposed to H
2
O. H
2
O (1 μL) was dropped onto the surface of each HTL, and then the absorption spectrum of the bilayer was acquired after the H
2
O drop had disappeared (
Figure 6
b). We found the relative absorption at ∼700 nm of the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
film was more intensive compared to that of spiro-OMeTAD. This might be due to the absorption by DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
, which has a maximum point at 724 nm and covers up to 800 nm, whereas spiro-OMeTAD shows relatively weak absorption in this range. The degree of absorbance reduction at 700 nm (
A
red
(%)) after the introduction of the H
2
O drop (
A
red
(%) = (
A
o
–
A
w
)/
A
o
× 100,
A
o
: initial absorbance,
A
w
: absorbance after H
2
O drop disappears) provides a measure of how fast H
2
O diffuses into the HTM and then meets the perovskite layer. Water molecules on a HTL with high moisture permeability are likely to easily intrude into the HTM, whereas water molecules on a HTL with low moisture permeability are likely to evaporate before intrusion; the degrees of absorbance reduction (
A
red
(%)) are 37.4 and 2.01% for doped spiro-OMeTAD and DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
, respectively. The hydrophobic DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
HTM appears to act as a barrier to moisture ingress, whereas doped spiro-OMeTAD cannot prevent the perovskite decomposition process due to intrusion of H
2
O. To study the effects of the extended D′–A–D–A–D–A–D′ π-structure on the moisture permeability of the HTM, we prepared D–A-type analogues of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
with two different molecular sizes, as shown in
Figure S7
: Compounds 4 and 5 were prepared by removing FBT and DTS units from DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
and thus, compound 4 has the smallest molecular size, followed by compound 5. Stability tests were performed for MAPbI
3
/HTM (compounds 4 and 5) films under the same experimental conditions as described above.
Figure S8
shows the UV–vis spectra of the MAPbI
3
/HTM films before and after the H
2
O drop, and the values (
A
red
(%)) of the MAPbI
3
/HTM films are compared in
Figure 6
c. The perovskite films protected by the dopant-free D–A-type compounds exhibit less degradation than that protected by doped spiro-OMeTAD. This difference probably arises because of the hydrophobic nature of the undoped D–A-type compounds. In particular, the presence of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
results in the lowest degree of degradation and the highest improvement in perovskite stability. The presence of compound 5 results in the next lowest degree of degradation, followed by compound 4. We investigated the cross-sectional morphologies of the degraded perovskite layer after the H
2
O dropping tests with SEM. The SEM images in
Figure 6
d show that the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
-based film nearly retained its initial morphology, whereas the film using doped spiro-OMeTAD underwent morphological changes; many small pieces of crystal, thought to be hydrate crystals of MAPbI
3
, can be observed.
(35)
After degradation, similar morphological changes can be seen in the film using compound 4 (
Figure S9
), which suggests that moisture easily intrudes into the HTM and that compound 4 cannot effectively protect the perovskite layer from moisture as much as DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
. On the basis of these results, it is clear that the size of the HTM molecule affects its ability to protect the underlying perovskite film. Further, the extended π-structure slows the permeation of water through the HTM film. These observations can be explained with the following mechanism although further detailed studies are necessary. Water vapor is able to percolate through the empty spaces between the HTM molecules and decomposes the perovskite material when it reaches the lower perovskite layer. DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
can form dense and compact films with small intermolecular spaces due to its extended π-structure; the π–π stacking distance measured in the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
film is 3.55 Å, which is one of the shortest π–π stacking distances observed for organic semiconductors, and this suggests that the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
molecules form HTM films with a high packing density.
(36)
In contrast, small molecules such as compound 4 may exhibit relatively less effective π–π stacking and more spaces between the molecules in the film, which results in less dense molecular packing. We studied the absorption properties of the molecules. As shown in the spectra (
Figure S10
), the absorption onset points (λ
onset
’s) in the film were red-shifted compared with those of the corresponding ones in solution for all compounds, and the absorption maxima (λ
max
’s) in the film were also red-shifted for compound 5 and DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
. The λ
onset
and λ
max
values in the solution and film are summarized in
Figure S10
, and the degree of red shift from solution to film was calculated using Δλ = λ(film) – λ(solution). The degree of red shift increased in the order of compound 4 < compound 5 < DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
. In the film, the shoulder peak at long wavelengths is usually enhanced and red-shifted compared with that in the solution due to the planarization of molecular backbones and the effective intermolecular packing. Thus, from Δλ
onset
(or Δλ
max
), we expect that DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
has a higher degree of molecular packing than that of the other compounds. Therefore, water molecules can permeate into the compound 4 layer relatively easily. The HTL of the intermediate-sized compound 5 may be better than compound 4 at slowing down water intrusion into the perovskite layer but not as effective as DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
. These results demonstrate that a dopant-free hydrophobic HTM with an extended π-structure is important for protecting the perovskite photoactive layer from outside moisture and thus improving device stability.

We have developed efficient planar structure perovskite solar cells employing a dopant-free small molecule HTM, DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2,
which has a D′–A–D–A–D–A–D′-type π-extended structure. The optimized device exhibits a high PCE of 17.3%, which is comparable in performance to that of the device using the current state-of-the-art doped spiro-OMeTAD HTM under equivalent conditions. This high performance is due to the efficient hole-extraction/collection and high hole transport properties of DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
. Furthermore, DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
-based solar cell devices exhibit much improved device stability under conditions of 60% RH in combination with 1 sun light-soaking. We demonstrated that its hydrophobic nature and the compact molecular packing structure in the DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
film, which is due to its extended π-structure, effectively slow moisture ingress into the HTL. As far as we know, the developed solar cell using DFBT(DTS-FBTTh
2
)
2
is the first example of a dopant-free HTM-based PSC that can simultaneously achieve high efficiency and device stability under humid and light-soaking conditions. The extended D′–A–D–A–D–A–D′-type small molecule is a promising dopant-free HTM for high performance perovskite solar cells with high stability.

span.span: Lead Iodide Perovskite Sensitized All-Solid-State Submicron Thin Film Mesoscopic Solar Cell with Efficiency Exceeding 9%

Lead iodide perovskite sensitized all-solid-state submicron thin film mesoscopic solar cell with efficiency exceeding 9%
Kim, Hui-Seon; Lee, Chang-Ryul; Im, Jeong-Hyeok; Lee, Ki-Beom; Moehl, Thomas; Marchioro, Arianna; Moon, Soo-Jin; Humphry-Baker, Robin; Yum, Jun-Ho; Moser, Jacques E.; Gratzel, Michael; Park, Nam-Gyu

We report on solid-state mesoscopic heterojunction solar cells employing nanoparticles (NPs) of Me ammonium lead iodide (CH3NH3)PbI3 as light harvesters. The perovskite NPs were produced by reaction of methylammonium iodide with PbI2 and deposited onto a submicron-thick mesoscopic TiO2 film, whose pores were infiltrated with the hole-conductor spiro-MeOTAD. Illumination with std. AM-1.5 sunlight generated large photocurrents (JSC) exceeding 17 mA/cm2, an open circuit photovoltage (VOC) of 0.888 V and a fill factor (FF) of 0.62 yielding a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 9.7%, the highest reported to date for such cells. Femto second laser studies combined with photo-induced absorption measurements showed charge sepn. to proceed via hole injection from the excited (CH3NH3)PbI3 NPs into the spiro-MeOTAD followed by electron transfer to the mesoscopic TiO2 film. The use of a solid hole conductor dramatically improved the device stability compared to (CH3NH3)PbI3-sensitized liq. junction cells.

Inorg.-org. hybrid structures have become innovative alternatives for next-generation dye-sensitized solar cells, because they combine the advantages of both systems. Here, we introduce a layered sandwich-type architecture, the core of which comprises a bicontinuous three-dimensional nanocomposite of mesoporous (mp)-TiO2, with CH3NH3PbI3 perovskite as light harvester, as well as a polymeric hole conductor. This platform creates new opportunities for the development of low-cost, soln.-processed, high-efficiency solar cells. The use of a polymeric hole conductor, esp. poly-triarylamine, substantially improves the open-circuit voltage Voc and fill factor of the cells. Solar cells based on these inorg.-org. hybrids exhibit a short-circuit c.d. Jsc of 16.5 mA cm-2, Voc of 0.997 V and fill factor of 0.727, yielding a power conversion efficiency of 12.0% under std. AM 1.5 conditions.

Stranks, Samuel D.; Eperon, Giles E.; Grancini, Giulia; Menelaou, Christopher; Alcocer, Marcelo J. P.; Leijtens, Tomas; Herz, Laura M.; Petrozza, Annamaria; Snaith, Henry J.

Org.-inorg. perovskites showed promise as high-performance absorbers in solar cells, 1st as a coating on a mesoporous metal oxide scaffold and more recently as a solid layer in planar heterojunction architectures. Here, the authors report transient absorption and photoluminescence-quenching measurements to det. the electron-hole diffusion lengths, diffusion consts., and lifetimes in mixed halide (MeNH3PbI3-xClx) and triiodide (MeNH3PbI3) perovskite absorbers. The diffusion lengths are >1 μm in the mixed halide perovskite, which is an order of magnitude greater than the absorption depth. But the triiodide absorber has electron-hole diffusion lengths of about 100 nm. These results justify the high efficiency of planar heterojunction perovskite solar cells and identify a crit. parameter to optimize for future perovskite absorber development.

Low-temp. soln.-processed photovoltaics suffer from low efficiencies because of poor exciton or electron-hole diffusion lengths (typically ∼10 nm). Recent reports of highly efficient CH3NH3PbI3-based solar cells in a broad range of configurations raise a compelling case for understanding the fundamental photophys. mechanisms in these materials. By applying femtosecond transient optical spectroscopy to bilayers that interface this perovskite with either selective-electron or selective-hole extn. materials, the authors have uncovered concrete evidence of balanced long-range electron-hole diffusion lengths of at least 100 nm in soln.-processed CH3NH3PbI3. The high photoconversion efficiencies of these systems stem from the comparable optical absorption length and charge-carrier diffusion lengths, transcending the traditional constraints of soln.-processed semiconductors.

A review; it is not often that the scientific community is blessed with a material, which brings enormous hopes and receives special attention. When it does, it expands at a rapid pace and its every dimension creates curiosity. One such material is perovskite, which has triggered the development of new device architectures in energy conversion. Perovskites are of great interest in photovoltaic devices due to their panchromatic light absorption and ambipolar behavior. Power conversion efficiencies have been doubled in less than a year and over 15 % is being now measured in labs. Every digit increment in efficiency is being celebrated widely in the scientific community and is being discussed in industry. Here we provide a summary on the use of perovskite for inexpensive solar cells fabrication. It will not be unrealistic to speculate that one day perovskite-based solar cells can match the capability and capacity of existing technologies.

Here we combine the promising, owing to its comparatively narrow bandgap, but relatively unstable formamidinium lead iodide (FAPbI3) with methylammonium lead bromide (MAPbBr3) as the light-harvesting unit in a bilayer solar cell architecture. We investigated phase stability, morphol. of the perovskite layer, hysteresis in current-voltage characteristics, and overall performance as a function of chem. compn. Our results show that incorporation of MAPbBr3 into FAPbI3 stabilizes the perovskite phase of FAPbI3 and improves the power conversion efficiency of the solar cell to >18% under a std. illumination of 100 mW/cm2. These findings further emphasize the versatility and performance potential of inorg.-org. lead halide perovskite materials for photovoltaic applications.

The band gap of formamidinium lead iodide (FAPbI3) perovskites allows broader absorption of the solar spectrum relative to conventional methylammonium lead iodide (MAPbI3). Because the optoelectronic properties of perovskite films are closely related to film quality, deposition of dense and uniform films is crucial for fabricating high-performance perovskite solar cells (PSCs). An approach is reported for depositing high-quality FAPbI3 films, involving FAPbI3 crystn. by the direct intramol. exchange of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) mols. intercalated in PbI2 with formamidinium iodide. This process produces FAPbI3 films with (111)-preferred crystallog. orientation, large-grained dense microstructures, and flat surfaces without residual PbI2. Using films prepd. by this technique, the FAPbI3-based PSCs are fabricated with max. power conversion efficiency greater than 20%.

Polymer-templated nucleation and crystal growth of perovskite films for solar cells with efficiency greater than 21%
Bi, Dongqin; Yi, Chenyi; Luo, Jingshan; Decoppet, Jean-David; Zhang, Fei; Zakeeruddin, Shaik Mohammed; Li, Xiong; Hagfeldt, Anders; Gratzel, Michael

The past several years have witnessed the rapid emergence of a class of solar cells based on mixed org.-inorg. halide perovskites. Today's state-of-the-art perovskite solar cells (PSCs) employ various methods to enhance nucleation and improve the smoothness of the perovskite films formed via soln. processing. However, the lack of precise control over the crystn. process creates a risk of forming unwanted defects, for example, pinholes and grain boundaries. Here, we introduce an approach to prep. perovskite films of high electronic quality by using poly(Me methacrylate) (PMMA) as a template to control nucleation and crystal growth. We obtain shiny smooth perovskite films of excellent electronic quality, as manifested by a remarkably long photoluminescence lifetime. We realize stable PSCs with excellent reproducibility showing a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of up to 21.6% and a certified PCE of 21.02% under std. AM 1.5G reporting conditions.

A molecularly engineered hole-transporting material for efficient perovskite solar cells

Soln.-processable perovskite solar cells have recently achieved certified power conversion efficiencies of over 20%, challenging the long-standing perception that high efficiencies must come at high costs. One major bottleneck for increasing the efficiency even further is the lack of suitable hole-transporting materials, which ext. pos. charges from the active light absorber and transmit them to the electrode. In this work, we present a molecularly engineered hole-transport material with a simple dissym. fluorene-dithiophene (FDT) core substituted by N,N-di-p-methoxyphenylamine donor groups, which can be easily modified, providing the blueprint for a family of potentially low-cost hole-transport materials. We use FDT on state-of-the-art devices and achieve power conversion efficiencies of 20.2% which compare favorably with control devices with 2,2',7,7'-tetrakis(N,N-di-p-methoxyphenylamine)-9,9'-spirobifluorene (spiro-OMeTAD). Thus, this new hole transporter has the potential to replace spiro-OMeTAD.

Non-wetting surface-driven high-aspect-ratio crystalline grain growth for efficient hybrid perovskite solar cells
Bi, Cheng; Wang, Qi; Shao, Yuchuan; Yuan, Yongbo; Xiao, Zhengguo; Huang, Jinsong

Large-aspect-ratio grains are needed in polycryst. thin-film solar cells for reduced charge recombination at grain boundaries; however, the grain size in organolead trihalide perovskite (OTP) films is generally limited by the film thickness. Here we report the growth of OTP grains with high av. aspect ratio of 2.3-7.9 on a wide range of non-wetting hole transport layers (HTLs), which increase nucleus spacing by suppressing heterogeneous nucleation and facilitate grain boundary migration in grain growth by imposing less drag force. The reduced grain boundary area and improved crystallinity dramatically reduce the charge recombination in OTP thin films to the level in OTP single crystals. Combining the high work function of several HTLs, a high stabilized device efficiency of 18.3% in low-temp.-processed planar-heterojunction OTP devices under 1 sun illumination is achieved. This simple method in enhancing OTP morphol. paves the way for its application in other optoelectronic devices for enhanced performance.

Walker, Bright; Tamayo, Arnold B.; Dang, Xuan-Dung; Zalar, Peter; Seo, Jung Hwa; Garcia, Andres; Tantiwiwat, Mananya; Nguyen, Thuc-Quyen

Research relating to org. solar cells based on soln.-processed, bulk heterojunction (BHJ) films has been dominated by polymeric donor materials, as they typically have better film-forming characteristics and film morphol. than their small-mol. counterparts. Despite these morphol. advantages, semiconducting polymers suffer from synthetic reproducibility and difficult purifn. procedures, which hinder their com. viability. Here, a non-polymeric, diketopyrrolopyrrole-based donor material that can be soln. processed with a fullerene acceptor to produce good quality films is reported. Thermal annealing leads to suitable phase sepn. and material distribution so that highly effective BHJ morphologies are obtained. The frontier orbitals of the material are well aligned with those of the fullerene acceptor, allowing efficient electron transfer and suitable open-circuit voltages, leading to power conversion efficiencies of 4.4 ± 0.4% under AM1.5G illumination (100 mW cm-2). Small mols. can therefore be soln. processed to form high-quality BHJ films, which may be used for low-cost, flexible org. solar cells.

Efficient OPV materials can be constructed by the attachment of planar, sym., end groups to electroactive small mols. Appending C2-pyrene as the small mol. end group results in materials with tight, aligned crystal packing and favorable morphol. dictated by π-π interactions. The intermol. connectivity promoted by C2-pyrene allows devices contg. blends of a diketopyrrolopyrrole and PC71BM to reach a max. PCE above 4% with a FF approaching 0.6. The use of end-groups to direct mol. self-assembly represents an effective strategy for designing high-performance small mol. OPV devices.

The exploration of alternative mol. hole-transporting materials (HTMs) specifically for high performance perovskite solar cells (PSCs) is a relatively recent research area. Aiming for further increasing the 'efficiency-cost ratio' of PSCs, we developed a spiro[fluorene-9,9'-xanthene] based HTM (X59) via two-step synthesis from com. precursors for perovskite solar cells (PSCs) that works as effectively as the well-known HTM-Spiro-OMeTAD-based device under the same conditions. The mol. structure was analyzed by X-ray crystallog. indicating a similar packing regime as for Spiro-OMeTAD. An impressive PCE of 19.8% was achieved by using X59 as HTM in PSC, which can compete with the record PCE of 20.8% by using the state-of-the-art-HTM Spiro-OMeTAD (Tress et al., 2016) [1]. The optimized devices employing X59 as HTM exhibited minimized hysteresis, excellent reproducibility and reasonable stability under dark and dry conditions. The present finding highlights the potential of spiro-type HTM for high performance PSCs and paves the way to a much deceased fabrication cost for potential commercialization of perovskite solar panels.

Org.-inorg. perovskite solar cells have recently emerged at the forefront of photovoltaics research. Power conversion efficiencies have experienced an unprecedented increase to reported values exceeding 19% within just four years. With the focus mainly on efficiency, the aspect of stability has so far not been thoroughly addressed. In this paper, the thermal stability is identified as a fundamental weak point of perovskite solar cells, and an elegant approach is demonstrated to mitigating thermal degrdn. by replacing the org. hole transport material with polymer-functionalized single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) embedded in an insulating polymer matrix. With this composite structure, JV scanned power-conversion efficiencies are obtained of up to 15.3% with an av. efficiency of 10 ± 2%. Moreover, strong retardation is obsd. in thermal degrdn. as compared to cells employing state-of-the-art org. hole-transporting materials. In addn., the resistance to water ingress is remarkably enhanced. These are crit. developments for achieving long-term stability of high-efficiency perovskite solar cells.

In this paper, an electron donor-acceptor (D-A) substituted dipolar chromophore (BTPA-TCNE) is developed to serve as an efficient dopant-free hole-transporting material (HTM) for perovskite solar cells (PVSCs). BTPA-TCNE is synthesized via a simple reaction between a triphenylamine-based Michler's base and tetracyanoethylene. This chromophore possesses a zwitterionic resonance structure in the ground state, as evidenced by X-ray crystallog. and transient absorption spectroscopies. Moreover, BTPA-TCNE shows an antiparallel mol. packing (i.e., centrosym. dimers) in its cryst. state, which cancels out its overall mol. dipole moment to facilitate charge transport. As a result, BTPA-TCNE can be employed as an effective dopant-free HTM to realize an efficient (PCE ≈ 17.0%) PVSC in the conventional n-i-p configuration, outperforming the control device with doped spiro-OMeTAD HTM.

Spectral engineering in π-conjugated polymers with intramolecular donor-acceptor interactions
Beaujuge, Pierre M.; Amb, Chad M.; Reynolds, John R.
Accounts of Chemical Research
(

A review. With the development of light-harvesting org. materials for solar cell applications and mol. systems with fine-tuned colors for nonemissive electrochromic devices (e.g., smart windows, e-papers), a no. of tech. challenges remain to be overcome. Over the years, the concept of "spectral engineering" (tailoring the complex interplay between mol. physics and the various optical phenomena occurring across the electromagnetic spectrum) has become increasingly relevant in the field of π-conjugated org. polymers. Within the spectral engineering toolbox, the "donor-acceptor" approach uses alternating electron-rich and electron-deficient moieties along a π-conjugated backbone. This approach has proved esp. valuable in the synthesis of dual-band and broadly absorbing chromophores with useful photovoltaic and electrochromic properties. In this Account, we highlight and provide insight into a present controversy surrounding the origin of the dual band of absorption sometimes encountered in semiconducting polymers structured using the "donor-acceptor" approach. Based on empirical evidence, we provide some schematic representations to describe the possible mechanisms governing the evolution of the two-band spectral absorption obsd. on varying the relative compn. of electron-rich and electron-deficient substituents along the π-conjugated backbone. In parallel, we draw attention to the choice of the method employed to est. and compare the absorption coeffs. of polymer chromophores exhibiting distinct repeat unit lengths, and contg. various extents of solubilizing side-chains along their backbone. Finally, we discuss the common assumption that "donor-acceptor" systems should have systematically lower absorption coeffs. than their "all-donor" counterparts. The proposed models point toward important theor. parameters which could be further explored at the macromol. level to help researchers take full advantage of the complex interactions taking place in π-conjugated polymers with intramol. "donor-acceptor" characteristics.

JAPIAU
; ISSN:
0021-8979
.
(
American Institute of Physics
)
Hole transport in the org. small mol. material 2,2',7,7'-tetrakis-(N,N-di-4-methoxyphenylamino)-9,9'-spirobifluorene (methoxy-spiro) is studied by three different exptl. techniques: Time of flight (TOF), dark-injection space-charge-limited current transients and steady-state current-voltage characteristics, and over a wide range of elec. fields, sample thicknesses and temps. It is shown that room-temp. mobilities measured by all three methods agree well over a range of studied thicknesses from 4 μm down to 135 nm. Temp.-dependent TOF measurements are analyzed within the Gaussian disorder model and the parameters of charge transport in this material are extd. Comparison with the data reported for other spirolinked compds. indicate a significant increase of the mobility prefactor in the methoxy-spiro, which is attributed to the increased spread of the HOMO wave function in this material.

Leijtens, Tomas; Ding, I-Kang; Giovenzana, Tommaso; Bloking, Jason T.; McGehee, Michael D.; Sellinger, Alan

We present the synthesis and device characterization of new hole transport materials for application in solid-state dye-sensitized solar cells (ssDSSCs). In addn. to possessing elec. properties well suited for ssDSSCs, these new hole transport materials have low glass transition temps., low m.ps., and high soly., which make them promising candidates for increased pore filling into mesoporous titania films. Using std. device fabrication methods and Z907 as the sensitizing dye, power conversion efficiencies of 2.94% in 2-μm-thick cells were achieved, rivaling the power conversion efficiencies obtained by control devices using the state-of-the-art hole transport material spiro-OMeTAD. In 6-μm-thick cells, the device performance is shown to be higher than that obtained using spiro-OMeTAD, making these new hole transport materials promising for prepg. high-efficiency ssDSSCs.

Influence of ionizing dopants on charge transport in organic semiconductors
Abate, Antonio; Staff, Daniel R.; Hollman, Derek J.; Snaith, Henry J.; Walker, Alison B.
Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics
(
2014
),
16
(
3
),
1132-1138
CODEN:
PPCPFQ
; ISSN:
1463-9076
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Ionizing chem. dopants are widely used in org. semiconductors to enhance the charge transport properties by increasing the no. of mobile charge carriers. However, together with mobile charges, chem. doping produces anion-cation pairs in the org. matrix. The authors use exptl. and computational anal. to study the influence of these ionic species on the charge transport. The anion-cation pairs introduced upon doping have a detrimental, doping-level dependent effect on charge mobility. For doping levels of 0.02-0.05% molar ratio with respect to the mol. org. semiconductor, the increase in cond. from the extra mobile charges is partially cancelled by a redn. in charge mobility from traps introduced by the anion-cation pairs. As the doping concn. increases, anion-cation pairs start to overlap, resulting in a comparatively smoother potential landscape, which increases the charge mobility to values closer to the undoped semiconductor. This result has a significant, practical impact, as it shows the need to dope at or slightly above a threshold level, which depends on the specific host-dopant combination.

Hysteresis-less inverted CH3NH3PbI3 planar perovskite hybrid solar cells with 18.1% power conversion efficiency
Heo, Jin Hyuck; Han, Hye Ji; Kim, Dasom; Ahn, Tae Kyu; Im, Sang Hyuk
Energy & Environmental Science

Hysteresis-less inverted ITO/PEDOT:PSS/CH3NH3PbI3 (MAPbI3)/PCBM/Au planar hybrid solar cells with 18.1% av. power conversion efficiency irresp. of the scan rate were fabricated by depositing dense pinhole-free MAPbI3 perovskite on a PEDOT:PSS/ITO substrate via a single-step spin-coating of soly. controlled MAPbI3 soln. The conductivities of PEDOT:PSS, PCBM, poly(triaryl amine) (PTAA):tert-butylpyrridne (tBP) + Li-bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (Li-TFSI), MAPbI3, and TiO2 were 0.014, 0.016, 0.034, 0.015, and 0.00006 mS cm-1, resp. The av. PL lifetimes (τav) of the inverted and normal cell were 1.277 and 1.94 ns, resp. The diffusion coeff. (Dn) and charge carrier lifetime (τn) for the inverted MAPbI3 planar hybrid solar cells were increased by 1.14-fold and 1.1-fold, resp., compared with the conventional FTO/TiO2/MAPbI3/PTAA:tBP + Li-TFSI/Au planar hybrid cells. Hence, the inverted MAPbI3 planar hybrid solar cells exhibited better power conversion efficiency and stability than the conventional MAPbI3 cells because (i) the electron extn. from MAPbI3 to the electron conductor was improved because the electron cond. of PCBM is higher than that of TiO2; (ii) the EQE value was increased by the better charge injection/sepn. efficiency between MAPbI3 and PCBM, and by the higher charge collection efficiency than the conventional cell; (iii) the fill factor is improved by the increased Dn and τn; and (iv) the air and humidity stability is improved by the absence of corrosive additives in the device architecture and the hydrophobicity of the PCBM top layer. The reduced c.d.-voltage (J-V) hysteresis with respect to the scan rate and scan direction in the inverted planar hybrid solar cells could be attributed to a more balanced electron flux (Je) and hole flux (Jh), and a reduced no. of surface traps.

Niu, Guangda; Guo, Xudong; Wang, Liduo

This review summarizes recent studies of the relationship of the chem. stability of perovskite solar cells with their environment (oxygen and moisture, UV light, soln. process, temp.) and corresponding possible solns. In recent years, the record efficiency of perovskite solar cells has been updated from 9.7% to 20.1%. However, there has been very little study of the issue of stability, which restricts the outdoor application of perovskite solar cells. The issues of the degrdn. of perovskite and the stability of perovskite solar cell devices should be urgently addressed to achieve good reproducibility and long lifetimes for perovskite solar cells with high conversion efficiency. Without studies on stability, exciting achievements cannot be transferred from the lab. to industry and outdoor applications. In order to improve their stability, a basic understanding of the degrdn. process of perovskite solar cells in different conditions should be acquired via thorough study.

Organometal halide perovskite solar cells: degradation and stability
Berhe, Taame Abraha; Su, Wei-Nien; Chen, Ching-Hsiang; Pan, Chun-Jern; Cheng, Ju-Hsiang; Chen, Hung-Ming; Tsai, Meng-Che; Chen, Liang-Yih; Dubale, Amare Aregahegn; Hwang, Bing-Joe
Energy & Environmental Science

(

323-356
CODEN:
EESNBY
; ISSN:
1754-5706
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Organometal halide perovskite solar cells have evolved in an exponential manner in the two key areas of efficiency and stability. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) reached 20.1% late last year. The key disquiet was stability, which has been limiting practical application, but now the state of the art is promising, being measured in thousands of hours. These improvements have been achieved through the application of different materials, interfaces and device architecture optimizations, esp. after the investigation of hole conductor free mesoporous devices incorporating carbon electrodes, which promise stable, low cost and easy device fabrication methods. However, this work is still far from complete. There are various issues assocd. with the degrdn. of Omh-perovskite, and the interface and device instability which must be addressed to achieve good reproducibility and long lifetimes for Omh-PSCs with high conversion efficiencies. A comprehensive understanding of these issues is required to achieve breakthroughs in stability and practical outdoor applications of Omh-PSCs. For successful small and large scale applications, besides the improvement of the PCE, the stability of Omh-PSCs has to be improved. The causes of failure and assocd. mechanisms of device degrdn., followed by the origins of degrdn., approaches to improve stability, and methods and protocols are discussed in detail and form the main focus of this review article.

Transformation of the excited state and photovoltaic efficiency of CH3NH3PbI3 perovskite upon controlled exposure to humidified air
Christians, Jeffrey A.; Miranda Herrera, Pierre A.; Kamat, Prashant V.
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(
2015
),
137
(
4
),
1530-1538
CODEN:
JACSAT
; ISSN:
0002-7863
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Humidity has been an important factor, in both neg. and pos. ways, in the development of perovskite solar cells and will prove crit. in the push to commercialize this exciting new photovoltaic technol. The interaction between CH3NH3PbI3 and H2O vapor is investigated by characterizing the ground-state and excited-state optical absorption properties and probing morphol. and crystal structure. These undertakings reveal that H2O exposure does not simply cause CH3NH3PbI3 to revert to PbI2. It is shown that, in the dark, H2O is able to complex with the perovskite, forming a hydrate product similar to (CH3NH3)4PbI6·2H2O. This causes a decrease in absorption across the visible region of the spectrum and a distinct change in the crystal structure of the material. Femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopic measurements show the effect that humidity has on the ultrafast excited state dynamics of CH3NH3PbI3. More importantly, the deleterious effects of humidity on complete solar cells, specifically on photovoltaic efficiency and stability, are explored in the light of these spectroscopic understandings.

We report on solid-state mesoscopic heterojunction solar cells employing nanoparticles (NPs) of Me ammonium lead iodide (CH3NH3)PbI3 as light harvesters. The perovskite NPs were produced by reaction of methylammonium iodide with PbI2 and deposited onto a submicron-thick mesoscopic TiO2 film, whose pores were infiltrated with the hole-conductor spiro-MeOTAD. Illumination with std. AM-1.5 sunlight generated large photocurrents (JSC) exceeding 17 mA/cm2, an open circuit photovoltage (VOC) of 0.888 V and a fill factor (FF) of 0.62 yielding a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 9.7%, the highest reported to date for such cells. Femto second laser studies combined with photo-induced absorption measurements showed charge sepn. to proceed via hole injection from the excited (CH3NH3)PbI3 NPs into the spiro-MeOTAD followed by electron transfer to the mesoscopic TiO2 film. The use of a solid hole conductor dramatically improved the device stability compared to (CH3NH3)PbI3-sensitized liq. junction cells.

Org.-inorg. perovskites showed promise as high-performance absorbers in solar cells, 1st as a coating on a mesoporous metal oxide scaffold and more recently as a solid layer in planar heterojunction architectures. Here, the authors report transient absorption and photoluminescence-quenching measurements to det. the electron-hole diffusion lengths, diffusion consts., and lifetimes in mixed halide (MeNH3PbI3-xClx) and triiodide (MeNH3PbI3) perovskite absorbers. The diffusion lengths are >1 μm in the mixed halide perovskite, which is an order of magnitude greater than the absorption depth. But the triiodide absorber has electron-hole diffusion lengths of about 100 nm. These results justify the high efficiency of planar heterojunction perovskite solar cells and identify a crit. parameter to optimize for future perovskite absorber development.

Low-temp. soln.-processed photovoltaics suffer from low efficiencies because of poor exciton or electron-hole diffusion lengths (typically ∼10 nm). Recent reports of highly efficient CH3NH3PbI3-based solar cells in a broad range of configurations raise a compelling case for understanding the fundamental photophys. mechanisms in these materials. By applying femtosecond transient optical spectroscopy to bilayers that interface this perovskite with either selective-electron or selective-hole extn. materials, the authors have uncovered concrete evidence of balanced long-range electron-hole diffusion lengths of at least 100 nm in soln.-processed CH3NH3PbI3. The high photoconversion efficiencies of these systems stem from the comparable optical absorption length and charge-carrier diffusion lengths, transcending the traditional constraints of soln.-processed semiconductors.

A review; it is not often that the scientific community is blessed with a material, which brings enormous hopes and receives special attention. When it does, it expands at a rapid pace and its every dimension creates curiosity. One such material is perovskite, which has triggered the development of new device architectures in energy conversion. Perovskites are of great interest in photovoltaic devices due to their panchromatic light absorption and ambipolar behavior. Power conversion efficiencies have been doubled in less than a year and over 15 % is being now measured in labs. Every digit increment in efficiency is being celebrated widely in the scientific community and is being discussed in industry. Here we provide a summary on the use of perovskite for inexpensive solar cells fabrication. It will not be unrealistic to speculate that one day perovskite-based solar cells can match the capability and capacity of existing technologies.

Here we combine the promising, owing to its comparatively narrow bandgap, but relatively unstable formamidinium lead iodide (FAPbI3) with methylammonium lead bromide (MAPbBr3) as the light-harvesting unit in a bilayer solar cell architecture. We investigated phase stability, morphol. of the perovskite layer, hysteresis in current-voltage characteristics, and overall performance as a function of chem. compn. Our results show that incorporation of MAPbBr3 into FAPbI3 stabilizes the perovskite phase of FAPbI3 and improves the power conversion efficiency of the solar cell to >18% under a std. illumination of 100 mW/cm2. These findings further emphasize the versatility and performance potential of inorg.-org. lead halide perovskite materials for photovoltaic applications.

The band gap of formamidinium lead iodide (FAPbI3) perovskites allows broader absorption of the solar spectrum relative to conventional methylammonium lead iodide (MAPbI3). Because the optoelectronic properties of perovskite films are closely related to film quality, deposition of dense and uniform films is crucial for fabricating high-performance perovskite solar cells (PSCs). An approach is reported for depositing high-quality FAPbI3 films, involving FAPbI3 crystn. by the direct intramol. exchange of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) mols. intercalated in PbI2 with formamidinium iodide. This process produces FAPbI3 films with (111)-preferred crystallog. orientation, large-grained dense microstructures, and flat surfaces without residual PbI2. Using films prepd. by this technique, the FAPbI3-based PSCs are fabricated with max. power conversion efficiency greater than 20%.

Today's state-of-the-art perovskite solar cells (PSCs) employ various methods to enhance nucleation and improve the smoothness of the perovskite films formed via soln. processing. However, the lack of precise control over the crystn. process creates a risk of forming unwanted defects, for example, pinholes and grain boundaries. Here, we introduce an approach to prep. perovskite films of high electronic quality by using poly(Me methacrylate) (PMMA) as a template to control nucleation and crystal growth. Soln.-processable perovskite solar cells have recently achieved certified power conversion efficiencies of over 20%, challenging the long-standing perception that high efficiencies must come at high costs. One major bottleneck for increasing the efficiency even further is the lack of suitable hole-transporting materials, which ext. pos. charges from the active light absorber and transmit them to the electrode. In this work, we present a molecularly engineered hole-transport material with a simple dissym. fluorene-dithiophene (FDT) core substituted by N,N-di-p-methoxyphenylamine donor groups, which can be easily modified, providing the blueprint for a family of potentially low-cost hole-transport materials. We use FDT on state-of-the-art devices and achieve power conversion efficiencies of 20.2% which compare favorably with control devices with 2,2',7,7'-tetrakis(N,N-di-p-methoxyphenylamine)-9,9'-spirobifluorene (spiro-OMeTAD). Thus, this new hole transporter has the potential to replace spiro-OMeTAD.

Research relating to org. solar cells based on soln.-processed, bulk heterojunction (BHJ) films has been dominated by polymeric donor materials, as they typically have better film-forming characteristics and film morphol. than their small-mol. counterparts. Despite these morphol. advantages, semiconducting polymers suffer from synthetic reproducibility and difficult purifn. procedures, which hinder their com. viability. Here, a non-polymeric, diketopyrrolopyrrole-based donor material that can be soln. processed with a fullerene acceptor to produce good quality films is reported. Thermal annealing leads to suitable phase sepn. and material distribution so that highly effective BHJ morphologies are obtained. The frontier orbitals of the material are well aligned with those of the fullerene acceptor, allowing efficient electron transfer and suitable open-circuit voltages, leading to power conversion efficiencies of 4.4 ± 0.4% under AM1.5G illumination (100 mW cm-2). Small mols. can therefore be soln. processed to form high-quality BHJ films, which may be used for low-cost, flexible org. solar cells.

Power conversion efficiencies have experienced an unprecedented increase to reported values exceeding 19% within just four years. With the focus mainly on efficiency, the aspect of stability has so far not been thoroughly addressed. In this paper, the thermal stability is identified as a fundamental weak point of perovskite solar cells, and an elegant approach is demonstrated to mitigating thermal degrdn. by replacing the org. hole transport material with polymer-functionalized single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWNTs) embedded in an insulating polymer matrix. With this composite structure, JV scanned power-conversion efficiencies are obtained of up to 15.3% with an av. efficiency of 10 ± 2%. Moreover, strong retardation is obsd. in thermal degrdn. as compared to cells employing state-of-the-art org. hole-transporting materials. Spectral engineering in π-conjugated polymers with intramolecular donor-acceptor interactions
Beaujuge, Pierre M.; Amb, Chad M.; Reynolds, John R.

A review. With the development of light-harvesting org. materials for solar cell applications and mol. systems with fine-tuned colors for nonemissive electrochromic devices (e.g., smart windows, e-papers), a no. of tech. challenges remain to be overcome. Over the years, the concept of "spectral engineering" (tailoring the complex interplay between mol. physics and the various optical phenomena occurring across the electromagnetic spectrum) has become increasingly relevant in the field of π-conjugated org. polymers. Within the spectral engineering toolbox, the "donor-acceptor" approach uses alternating electron-rich and electron-deficient moieties along a π-conjugated backbone. This approach has proved esp. valuable in the synthesis of dual-band and broadly absorbing chromophores with useful photovoltaic and electrochromic properties. In this Account, we highlight and provide insight into a present controversy surrounding the origin of the dual band of absorption sometimes encountered in semiconducting polymers structured using the "donor-acceptor" approach. Based on empirical evidence, we provide some schematic representations to describe the possible mechanisms governing the evolution of the two-band spectral absorption obsd. on varying the relative compn. of electron-rich and electron-deficient substituents along the π-conjugated backbone. In parallel, we draw attention to the choice of the method employed to est. and compare the absorption coeffs. of polymer chromophores exhibiting distinct repeat unit lengths, and contg. various extents of solubilizing side-chains along their backbone. Finally, we discuss the common assumption that "donor-acceptor" systems should have systematically lower absorption coeffs. than their "all-donor" counterparts. The proposed models point toward important theor. parameters which could be further explored at the macromol. level to help researchers take full advantage of the complex interactions taking place in π-conjugated polymers with intramol. "donor-acceptor" characteristics.

Ionizing chem. dopants are widely used in org. semiconductors to enhance the charge transport properties by increasing the no. of mobile charge carriers. However, together with mobile charges, chem. doping produces anion-cation pairs in the org. matrix. The authors use exptl. and computational anal. to study the influence of these ionic species on the charge transport. The anion-cation pairs introduced upon doping have a detrimental, doping-level dependent effect on charge mobility. For doping levels of 0.02-0.05% molar ratio with respect to the mol. org. semiconductor, the increase in cond. from the extra mobile charges is partially cancelled by a redn. in charge mobility from traps introduced by the anion-cation pairs. As the doping concn. increases, anion-cation pairs start to overlap, resulting in a comparatively smoother potential landscape, which increases the charge mobility to values closer to the undoped semiconductor. This result has a significant, practical impact, as it shows the need to dope at or slightly above a threshold level, which depends on the specific host-dopant combination.

This review summarizes recent studies of the relationship of the chem. stability of perovskite solar cells with their environment (oxygen and moisture, UV light, soln. process, temp.) and corresponding possible solns. In recent years, the record efficiency of perovskite solar cells has been updated from 9.7% to 20.1%. However, there has been very little study of the issue of stability, which restricts the outdoor application of perovskite solar cells. The issues of the degrdn. of perovskite and the stability of perovskite solar cell devices should be urgently addressed to achieve good reproducibility and long lifetimes for perovskite solar cells with high conversion efficiency. Without studies on stability, exciting achievements cannot be transferred from the lab. to industry and outdoor applications. In order to improve their stability, a basic understanding of the degrdn. process of perovskite solar cells in different conditions should be acquired via thorough study.

span.span: Organometal Halide Perovskite Solar Cells: Degradation and Stability

Organometal halide perovskite solar cells: degradation and stability
Berhe, Taame Abraha; Su, Wei-Nien; Chen, Ching-Hsiang; Pan, Chun-Jern; Cheng, Ju-Hsiang; Chen, Hung-Ming; Tsai, Meng-Che; Chen, Liang-Yih; Dubale, Amare Aregahegn; Hwang, Bing-Joe
Energy & Environmental Science
(
2016
),
9
(
2
),
323-356
CODEN:
EESNBY
; ISSN:
1754-5706
.
(
Royal Society of Chemistry
)
Organometal halide perovskite solar cells have evolved in an exponential manner in the two key areas of efficiency and stability. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) reached 20.1% late last year. The key disquiet was stability, which has been limiting practical application, but now the state of the art is promising, being measured in thousands of hours. These improvements have been achieved through the application of different materials, interfaces and device architecture optimizations, esp. after the investigation of hole conductor free mesoporous devices incorporating carbon electrodes, which promise stable, low cost and easy device fabrication methods. However, this work is still far from complete. There are various issues assocd. with the degrdn. of Omh-perovskite, and the interface and device instability which must be addressed to achieve good reproducibility and long lifetimes for Omh-PSCs with high conversion efficiencies. A comprehensive understanding of these issues is required to achieve breakthroughs in stability and practical outdoor applications of Omh-PSCs. For successful small and large scale applications, besides the improvement of the PCE, the stability of Omh-PSCs has to be improved. The causes of failure and assocd. mechanisms of device degrdn., followed by the origins of degrdn., approaches to improve stability, and methods and protocols are discussed in detail and form the main focus of this review article.

Transformation of the excited state and photovoltaic efficiency of CH3NH3PbI3 perovskite upon controlled exposure to humidified air
Christians, Jeffrey A.; Miranda Herrera, Pierre A.; Kamat, Prashant V.
Journal of the American Chemical Society
(
2015
),

(

CODEN:

; ISSN:
0002-7863
.
(
American Chemical Society
)
Humidity has been an important factor, in both neg. and pos. ways, in the development of perovskite solar cells and will prove crit. in the push to commercialize this exciting new photovoltaic technol. The interaction between CH3NH3PbI3 and H2O vapor is investigated by characterizing the ground-state and excited-state optical absorption properties and probing morphol. and crystal structure. These undertakings reveal that H2O exposure does not simply cause CH3NH3PbI3 to revert to PbI2. It is shown that, in the dark, H2O is able to complex with the perovskite, forming a hydrate product similar to (CH3NH3)4PbI6·2H2O. This causes a decrease in absorption across the visible region of the spectrum and a distinct change in the crystal structure of the material. Femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopic measurements show the effect that humidity has on the ultrafast excited state dynamics of CH3NH3PbI3. More importantly, the deleterious effects of humidity on complete solar cells, specifically on photovoltaic efficiency and stability, are explored in the light of these spectroscopic understandings.
